Posts.Title: Vitamins and Nutrition

Posts.Content: Hi Liz, I was also dx with Lobular BC. Mine was Stage III and Invasive with 9+ lymph nodes. I had just turned 43. My bio is at the bottom of this page. All the feelings and emotions you are feeling, everyone of us have had and you'll have more as the treatment, surgeries get started. There's nothing you could say to any of us that would be abnormal or be a shock. We've lived the nightmare. You might want to talk to your surgeon about a mastectomy vs. a lumpectomy, especially if you have node involvement or a large tumor. Lobular is prone to mirror itself in the other breast and the chances go up (not dramatically) depending on the size of the tumor and nodes involved if any. I opted to have the other breast removed as well to avoid it coming back in the other breast and going through chemo and radiation again. It may have never gone to the other breast, but I wanted to do everything humanly possible to avoid a reoccuance. And with what all I did, there are still no guarentees it won't come back. I was considered high risk because of my age and being Stage III. It's been 3 1/2 years and I'm doing good. I'm still with NED (No Evidence of Disease) and I'll have a bone scan, chest x-ray, tumor markers and all the routine labs that are done at each follow up visit. Cancer sucks and so does the treatment BUT it is doable and many work full time going through it. They have come a long way with nausea meds and treatment in general. You can and will get through this and before long, you'll start your new life, of life after BC and there is life after this. If you have any questions, please feel free to e-mail me as I don't get on her much anymore. Only 10% of women get Lobular......aren't we lucky....ugh Nancy

Posts.Title: Newly Diagnosed

Posts.Content: Hi, It's only natural to be worried. It seems everytime we turn around we're hearing of someone else being dx with cancer. A swollen lymph node could be from an infection BUT you are doing the smart thing by going to the doctor. Most of the time, the lump associated with breast cancer in the breast isn't painful, but mine was a little sore and I've heard from other ladies other the years that said theirs were painful. With this disease, there is no set of rules that it plays by. Family hx only accounts for 10-15% of all breast cancers. I had no family hx. 75% of lumps are B9, but the only good lump is one that's in a jar and that has been checked with pathology. Too many doctors still want us to "watch and wait". Mammograms are great tests, but they miss 45% of all BC in women under 50 and 35% of women over 50. That's why it's so important to have mammograms and to do Self Breast Exams. When is your appt? Know that you're in my prayers and just don't let the doctor blow you off. There are great doctors around and there are some who still don't understand that cancer knows no age limits, family history and doesn't really care if you're in excellent health or not........ it's a cruel disease, BUT the earlier it's caught, the easier to treat and the better prognosis. Keep us posted.

Posts.Title: Painful swelling

Posts.Content: The only thing an ultra sound can do is show if there is something there. It can NOT tell if it's B9 or malignant. I was told my ultra sound showed a B9 cyst.......... It ended up being a 5.5 cm malignant tumor. The only way to be 100% sure if something is B9 or not is to do a biopsy.

I'm confused about the "suspicious" when a biopsy is done, I would think it would tell for certain one way or another. Again, I didn't have a core biopsy, but I'm sure others will be a great help to you. Best wishes Nancy
Posts.Title: "suspicious" IDC

Posts.Content: Don't sell yourself short. Of course, any help you can get, definately take it. If there are days that you don't have help, you will still come through this just fine. VERY long story short.....a week before my biopsy, caught hubby cheating, he beat the crap out of me and went to live with his g/f. It would take a book to tell you the whole story, but my point is, I had to go through it alone. I didn't live in the same city as my family and since I never worked in the city I was living in, and just knew people that worked for the police department (now ex is a cop), I was not only going through treatments alone, but also having to go through court through all of it. It wasn't fun and at times it wasn't easy, but but your armour on and kick some cancer butt. I had a friend who came over at night when she could, but she worked and had a husband and kids to take care of, so it wasn't very often. If you need someone to talk to, I'll be glad to call you if after 9 central time is o.k. since that's when my cell goes free minutes. Don't mean to sound cheap, but I haven't been able to find a job yet since moving back to the city I lived in before I got married and where my family is. I'll be more then happy to be there to listen, answer questions, or anything else you need. If you just need to cry and someone to understand, I can do that too. Let me know by private message as we're not suppose to give out numbers on the board which is smart for safety reasons. There are alot of nuts in this world that love to find boards like these and get info. You WILL get through this, you really will. I didn't think I would but I did and don't think you'll feel like crap the whole time. The majority of women, myself included had days I was tired and felt like crap, but also had days that I felt like I was fine and wasn't going through treatment at all. What state are you in? Hugs Nancy

Posts.Title: Scared, new diagnosis, am I alone?

Posts.Content: Hi, I had my MRM and node disection 2/21/02. I was told by my surgeon that I would always have a heavy, numby feeling in my upper arm and side of arm where I had the nodes removed and he was so right. I've had a couple small bouts with lymphedema, where my arm would be 1/2 - 1" larger then the other one and achy, but I've been able to elevate it when I'm laying down or sitting and within a couple of days, it would be fine. I think you'll hear alot of the same as far as the heavy, numby feeling from other ladies too. I've pretty much gotten use to it as my new "normal". Take care Nancy

Posts.Title: Scared, new diagnosis, am I alone?

Posts.Content: My onco didn't do any tumor markers until I was about 1 1/2 year NED. He did them every 3 months at check up time to establish what was " normal" for me. The ones I'm having checked in a couple of weeks, is the 1st one in a year. They aren't reliable, but more reliable for picking up reoccurences then initial dx. If I'm having problems, he listens to my problems and does test if necessary even if my TM are normal. One the other hand, many times you can have, example bone mets, long before you have any symptoms. If my tumor markers start rising and continue to rise, then he'd check things out. He puts more stock in what I say then the tumor markers, but since he knows what is normal for me, if they all the sudden go out of the normal range, something could be up.

Posts.Title: What tests do you get after all treatment is over?

Posts.Content: Hi Doxdad, Like Jim, I need more info to try and help. There are many types of treatment for Stage IV ladies and I know many that have been Stage IV for MANY years and still leading happy lives. Have they said there is no more treatment available? There are SO many kinds of chemo, many taken by mouth and of course, the I.V. kind that do wonders for keeping Stage IV "stable" or even shrink them as far as where they can't be found anymore. I'm one of those that wouldn't travel to another State unless where I go wasn't doing a Trial that could help. If you have a really good onco, I don't think anywhere else knows anymore then another. If you are in a small city where you only have a choice of 1 or 2 oncos, then that's different. Small areas normally aren't able to participate in Trials, but those are usually only done after nothing else has worked. If her onco is saying there is nothing else that can be done, get a 2nd opinion!!!

Posts.Title: I must not have looked far enough...

Posts.Content: Just buy her a new computer of her own If she's like most of us, there's a lot of cat napping when you go through chemo and she'll probably find herself up late and up early and napping on and off. I still have problems with sleep. I think my body got use to not sleeping through the night, it doesn't know how to anymore. BUT, the dogs and cat remember all to well what time breakfast comes, so no matter what time I fall asleep, I'm up by 6 to a cat on my chest and one dog staring me in the face........LOL Keep us posted on what kind of chemo she'll be getting and hopefully we can give her some pointers. No doubt she's a compassionate lady working with cancer patients, but I'm sure she feels like a fish out of water when she's the patient. Most onco's consider the day of surgery, when the visable cancer is removed as the beginning of her living with NED (No Evidence of Disease) and some even the dx date so even though it doesn't feel like it, she's kickin butt already Is she getting AC and then Taxol or Taxotere or 4 rounds of AC only? I noticed that she had node involvement, how many nodes were cancerous? I had 9 and my onco said they would have treated me the same way, very aggressively even if I had fewer nodes or for that matter in my case, no nodes since my tumor was so large. If you or Karen are up late at night and need to talk, just send me an e-mail and there's a good chance I'll be on line or it won't be long. Hugs and prayers to you both.

Posts.Title: First time post!

Posts.Content: When I asked my surgeon what I had done to cause me to have BC because there was no family history, he told me that only accounts for about 10-15% of BC. I'm sure there are things that they think could play a factor in, like never having kids, but there are a whole lot of ladies out there with BC that had kids. He said the reason I have BC is because I'm a woman and have estrogen and progestine. Of coure I'm er/pr+ which says that my cancer was feeding off hormones, that why I'm now on Arimidex. I don't think they know why women are dx with BC who are er/pr-. I "think" the younger you are, the more likely you'll be er/pr-, but if I recall, 80% of a BC are er/pr+. Nancy

The posts sometimes may be blunt, but also in good taste and the other person knows that we want them to accept nothing less then a definate answer and the best care possible. Posts.Content: Hi Pastor Rich, I'm glad she did so well with her 1st chemo. My concerns would be, alot of people and catching the flu or something as has been said. The other is, some people feel the same through all their chemo treatments, some the 1st one is the worst and others, like me, each treatment got harder and harder. With my 1st one, I felt real tired for a couple of days and then felt great, but each one had more bad days. Fatigue is a given with chemo. If there is anyway to make a final decision after she's had her 3 round, or even 2 round, I'll play it by ear and see hows she's feeing. That's the "gone through chemo" version.. lol IF the onco says go for it then go for it. I'm just concerned about how she might feel the more chemo she gets. Hopefully she'll be one of the lucky ones and it not be bad the entire time. Nancy

Posts.Title: Accelerated tooth decay post chemo?

Posts.Content: Hi, I've never heard of a biopsy being done on a lymph node, but maybe that's something new some have started doing. Her taking hormones for menopause symptoms definitely should have been stopped. It's been studied and shown to increase the risk of breast cancer. I'm still amazed at the doctors who prescribe them when other drugs work just as good, if not better and don't increase the risk. Her being told to stop taking them doesn't mean that she's hormone positive or not. Even women who are negative, are told to never take them. Depending on the kind of cancer will determine the chemo's that will be used. Some seem to be more effective on one kind moreso then another kind. I thought there was "breast cancer", I didn't realize there were different kinds until I was dx. The most common kind is Ductal, and with nodes involved, it would be Invasive Ductal. Another kind is Lobular. In my case it was Invasive because I had it in 9 of my lymph nodes. The surgeon will know what kind it is, but I'm really surprised that they are giving your mom a size when surrounding tissue can be cancerous and that's included in the actual size. The tumor and surrounding tissue that was removed during my biopsy, was 3.5 cm. but when I had the mastectomy, there was an additional 2 cm of tissue that was cancerous. It's more then the actual "lump" that can and is involved unless it's "in situ", which hers wouldn't be since it's in node(s).

Posts.Title: E-string

Posts.Content: You're definitely been doing your homework and know a lot more about it then I did when I found out I had cancer. Any questions you have, don't hesitate to ask. Yes. If he opts for a lumpectomy and they don't take enough tissue and they don't get clean margins, they will have to go back and either take more tissue and hope they get clean margins or do a mastectomy. Also, if they do a lumpectomy and get clean margins and it ends up you mom has quite a few lymph nodes positive, she may opt for a mastectomy. There are so many unknowns right now. It might be that if your mom doesn't want to chance extra surgeries, that she tell the surgeon if when they get in there and there are quite a few suspicious looking lymph nodes and or the tissue surrounding the tumor looks suspicious, to go ahead with the mastectomy. I can tell you that after just turning 43 and going through a divorce, so it wasn't like my husband would learn to deal with me nothing having 1 or both breast, that surgeons can do really nice jobs as far as the scar looks. I don't look "mutilated" like so many think. I never thought about it because I had no family hx (boy did I have a lot to learn), but I might have thought the same thing. You really do get use to it. They now have prothesis that adhere to your skin and you can wear a regular bra. There are bathing suits for masectomy patients. Here we have a store that is nothing but wigs, bathing suits, bras, etc. etc. etc. for BC survivors. I'm not by any means telling her to have a mastectomy, but without knowing how many nodes are involved or the size of the actual tumor, I wouldn't rule it out. When I knew mine was 3.5 cm and no clean margins, I had no doubts I wanted it gone. I wanted the cancer out of me and have never regretted my decision. As far as the size of the tumor and the nodes, it changes the dx, but it's all a crap shoot. I had a large tumor, young and 9+ nodes and it's been over 5 1/2 years and I'm still doing great and living with NED (no evidence of disease). I've seen ladies with tiny tumors and no node involvment have it come back. Of course the smaller the better chance, but there are many of us with large tumors and lots of positive nodes that are 5 1/2 - 11 years NED and still counting. There's every reason to have hope and to believe your mom will do great!!! How old is your mom if you don't mind me asking?

Posts.Title: need advice on mom's biopsy results

Posts.Content: Hi Shelly, How long it takes to get chemo depends on what chemo you're getting. I got FEC and got all 3 at the same time. Some get AC and then Taxol or Taxotere, CMF etc. I'd definately bring a book to read. My onco's office had magazines, snacks, juices and all that good stuff but bringing a book will help the time pass. I'm assuming that to start off each treatment, everyone gets the same which would be nausea meds and decadron (steroids) before they actually start giving the chemo. Some chemos are drips and some have to be pushed and those the nurse will be right there with you and all the nurses that work for the cancer institute I go to were great and we'd just sit and talk about everything while they were giving the chemo. Where I went, sadly, they were open to 7:00p.m. even with all the rooms they had for chemo, it was always full, so your appt. might be the time they gave. I'm sure there are similiarities and differences depending on where you go, but the chairs I sat in were recliners and you could actually take a nap if you wanted to. Good luck and you'll do great Nancy

Posts.Title: one more chemo question...

Posts.Content: Hi Peggy, I'm not sure what kind of chemo you're taking. My info is at the bottom. I did have shortness of breat during chemo, but I also had times that my stomach would swell, almost like I was pregnant with twin elephants and past my due date......o.k. maybe not quite that bad, but you get the idea. I assumed it was either water retension or the bloating was causing pressure up high so I had trouble breathing. I don't think it started with me until about the 4th treatment, but of course we all react differently to chemo. Are your ankles swollen? I had to be put on lasix twice, not for fluid around my heart and lungs, but fluid period. After a few days on that, my ankle swelling went down and the breathing was better. I was also taking xanax and Paxil. I can't remember if I was taking that before it started or not. I don't know anyone that goes through this that couldn't use an anti-depressant and something for anxiety. If your onco doesn't suggest it, ask him. There's no point of this being any harder then it has to when there are meds out there to help. Something else I just thought about and no idea if it has anything to do with anything. Chemo put me into instant menopause, which might have contribuated to the stomach swelling, bloating etc. Keep and touch and keep asking questions until you get an answer, not just what it's not, what it is. Best wishes Nancy

Posts.Title: Shortness of breath

Posts.Content: Hi, You asked Wouldn't a biopsy prior to surgery be a better plan A biopsy is considered surgery even though you aren't completely put under, instead are given Versaid (or at least I was......the I don't give a *** shot). Again, I'm speaking from what they did with me and I'm sure there are many variations. I had an incisional biopsy and the surgeon removed the lump and tissue around it. I later found out he actually did a lumpectomy. Once it was confirmed that I had cancer, I opted for a mastectomy without a 2nd thought. I wanted no chances that the cancer could be somewhere else in the breast too. Had I not chosen a mastectomy, they would have gone back in to get "clean margins" which is where they remove more tissue around the area that has already been biopsied until they get tissue with no cancer cells in it. I've heard of ladies having 3 done before clean margins were gotten, but quite often they get clean margins with the 2nd try. They didn't do sentinal node biopsies when I was dx, or maybe because the size of the tumor, they expected to find node involvement. They removed all (16) of my lymph nodes at the same time as my mastectomy and 9 were positive. I'm confused at how they are already planning a treatment plan when they don't know what they will find. Alot of oncos give chemo to Stage I ladies routinely now to increase the chances of not having a reoccurence. There is no logic to this disease and many are treating with chemo even if there is no node involvement and the tumors are small. Of course as you can see in my case, that wasn't an option. My mammogram missed a large tumor and I had alot of + nodes. I started chemo about 4 weeks after my mastectomy and node disection so the time frame they are speaking of in regards to starting radiation sounds right. Again, I would want to know what is found before talking treatment. If they feel that the tumor is cancer, I would question why they aren't doing the sentinal node biopsy at the same time. It seems like alot of surgeries to accomplish the same thing as a couple could take. Obviously if they don't know or don't feel as certain as they can without a biopsy that it's cancer, then they wouldn't want to do a sentinal node biopsy. From what I understand and I could be wrong on this since I didn't have one, they have to inject the dye into the nipple a day or 2 before surgery and if I'm right, that would explain not doing it the same day as the incisional biopsy. I had my biopsy done and found out I had cancer on 2/14/02 and had the mastectomy/node disection on 2/21/02 so I got it over with as soon as possible, but if you aren't comfortable with what they are telling you, you can get a 2nd opinion and a couple of weeks isn't going to change the outcome. I was told that mine was a cyst even though I could feel an egg shaped lump that just popped up. They did an ultra sound and told me I had 2, 1 cm b9 cyst. I knew what I felt was one thing, not 2 and my gut told me to go somewhere else, which I did and well, you know the rest of the story. Listen to your gut, be your own advocate, use a doctor that you trust and don't settle for anything but the best treatment possible (and I'm not saying the doc you're talking about isn't giving you that). Best of luck and let us know. Hugs and prayers Nancy

Posts.Title: Questioning sequence of events

Posts.Content: Hi, My onco did the CA 27-29 for the 1st 5 years and the last time also did the CEA. He no longer is ordering them. Mine stayed between 5.0 and 15.1. I know ladies who stay in the upper normal range. I know it's scary and I'm sure I would be too, but what mine told me was he was watching to see a pattern. Some oncos don't even run them because they aren't always accurate. With some ladies they are a good indicator that something is wrong. With others, theirs are normal even though they are Stage IV. I'm surprised you're still being seen every 3 months with being Stage I and he's running the tumor markers every time. If they continually go up, then I'm sure he'll do a bone scan, PET Scan or others tests. For right now, try not to worry. The chances of yours coming back being Stage I is very low. Did you have chemo or no treatment?

Posts.Title: CA 27 29

Posts.Content: Me personally, I would take one of the chemos, the one her onco thinks is the most effective for her type of BC. She's Stage II and I wouldn't just take Arimidex or Femara. Most women are getting 4 rounds of AC for Stage I and no nodes. There is no rhyme or reason to this disease and I would get the big guns now and hopefully avoid it in the future. I've seen ladies that were Stage I and just took hormone therapy just to have reoccurences. Stage II, I just don't think it's worth the risk and not take chemo.

Posts.Title: Hormone therapy and no Chemo?

Posts.Content: HI, I can't answer all your concerns, but I can tell you this. I had a 5.5cm tumor and 9 positive lymph nodes out of 16. They did a CT Scan, bone scan, chest x-ray and tons of lab work before I started chemo and I had NO distant mets. Just because you had node involvement does not mean that it has spread to organs or your bone. I know 3 ladies, one like me had 9+ nodes, one had 15+ nodes and 1 had 11+ nodes and none had distant mets. I'm 2 years and 8 months NED (No evidence of disease) and the other ladies are 4 yeras out and 6 years out. YOu always hope you don't have node involvement, but it doesn't mean it's gone to organs. I've seen ladies with tiny tumors and no node involvement and they have had reoccurences to the liver or bones. There is no rhyme or reason to this disease, I guess that's where there is no cure. Things may have changed since I was dx, but my surgeon said that they check several blood vessels during my mastectomy and found no cancer cells in them BUT that didn't mean it hadn't gone into my blood stream from the nodes. Again, unless things have changed, there is no test to know for sure. Obviously if they found vascular invasion then it is in the blood stream, but either way, the treatment would be the same. Chemo and radiation. I had 6 rounds of Cytoxin, Epriubensin (sp) and 5FU and then 33 or 36 treatments of radiation (Thank God I'm starting to forget some of this nightmare). I'd sit down with the surgeon and/or oncologist and ask them to explain the parts you don't understand. This is a very emotional time and I always had someone go with me because my brain shut down after hearing just so much. Your wife will get in the "kick cancer butt" mode, like we all do and she'll get through all the treatments fine. It sucks, but she can do it. I know this is hard on you also, so don't hesistate to ask questions. Most don't ramble like me.. LOL Take care Nancy
Posts.Title: Lymphatic/Vascular invasion

Posts.Content: Hi Jill, I was 43 when I was dx and the chemo put me into menopause. I asked my onco about having my ovaries removed since I was Stage III and er/pr+. They did some kind of survey or questionaire thing and he said it wouldn't benefit me. I know your history will be different then mine of course because we are two different people. I personally have only heard of ladies getting medicine to put them into menopause if the onco is wanting to put them on Arimidex and you have to be post menopausal for that drug. That's all I know on the topic and I'm sure I wasn't any help. Hopefully someone else can explain it more or know what questions to ask. Take care Nancy

Posts.Title: Weekly CMF

Posts.Content: Hi, I'm so sorry to hear about your mom's dx. The most common places for Breast Cancer to come back to are the bones, lungs, liver and brain. Although not common, it can came back to the pancreas, kidneys and anywhere else it decides to mutate. Usually when it's mets vs a primary, it's more treatable, and as quickly as she's declining, to me it sounds more like primary pancreatic cancer, but I'm no doctor and I'm sure yours know what they are doing. I know it's possible, but having a recurrence after almost 30 years seems hard to believe, even though we're never safe from it happening. I pray that her pain is able to be controlled. She's so lucky to have you there with her. Please know you are in my thoughts and prayers.

Posts.Content: I'm thinking the same thing Jim. It must be 5 different tumors vs 5 different primary's. As far as your mom having to have chemo, it's doable. It's not fun, but not the horror stories that you heard way back when. I'd much rather have chemo (which I did) and give myself every chance possible to kill any cells floating around then not take chemo and it come back in different areas. Even though many Stage IV ladies are stable many years after it came back, that's not what any of us want to see happen.

Posts.Title: Bad news....

Posts.Content: Hi, I've never had kids, so I don't know if the discharges and everything are normal or not. You're young, but that doesn't mean anything. BC knows no age. I would find a breast specialist or a surgeon and let them look and see what's going on. Unfortunately, there are still a lot of docs who think if you're under 50, don't worry. I'm NOT by any means saying your situation is like mine. I found a lump, jump popped up from nowhere. I had a mammogram, it came back fine. I had an Utra Sound, said that was fine too and come back in a year. My gut said something wasn't right so I called my Family Doc and told her I wanted to see a surgeon. I did and the bottom is my bio of my dx. Again, this DOES NOT mean you have breast cancer, it's just to point out, if you are worried and you feel uneasy about the, you're fine, I would go with your gut, get checked out by someone who specializes in breast cancer and get things checked out. If it's nothing and there's a good chance it is nothing, you'll have peace of mind knowing that you were checked over by someone who deals with breast cancer and diseases of the breast. I've heard of too many gyn. who still TRY to prescribe hormones to women for menopause even though they are breast cancer survivors and were hormone receptive, meaning their cancer feeds on hormones, which the majority do. Please keep us posted and write anytime. I think on how you're feeling, there's little doubt you need definate answers and I don't blame you. When I was dx in 2/02, it was 1 in 9 women. Last year it was 1 out of 7, this year I've read both, 1 out of 7 and 1 out of 6. This disease is an epidemic and the government doesn't seem to realize it and we need more funding!!!! It's time for a CURE. Hugs and prayers and I'm here anytime. E-mail me anytime. Nancy

Posts.Title: Please help me - possible breast cancer

Posts.Content: I got the literature from my Plastic Surgeon's office along with pictures of what implants looked like vs real breasts. I know when I see someone on t.v. that is larger up top then most I can tell right away if they've had implants because of the before and after pictures I saw. Not they I sit and look at women's chest..... lol Next time you watch t.v. and you see someone with a low cut dress on they will either look like you did prior to your mastectomy or they will look rounded, the rounded ones are inplants. The PS did tell me upfront that they wouldn't look like natural breasts, that they would be round and that's why he recommended the LD Flap since I was to chicken to even consider the Tram Flap, because they use your own tissue, muscle etc and they look natural. Mine gave me literature, pictures, descriptions of the procedures of all 3 reconstruction choices. After 4 months of pain and have to remove some of the saline to give me a break from the pain, then trying again, and the expanders had to be removed, I decided I'd be boobless and I'm very happy with my decision. I'm not be any means telling you that you should do as I did, you have to feel good about your decision and you'll do what's best for you

Posts.Title: Lack of Info

Posts.Content: Hi Liz, Like you, I'd want a bone scan to be sure it wasn't bone mets but I can tell you from experience, Arimidex can cause some major pain. I had a bone scan because of hip pain that was new (had stiffness and pain in my finger joints/feet and ankles, which started shortly after the Arimidex). I just knew it was bone mets, but that's the 1st thing we think about. My bone scan was fine, showed some degenertive (sp) places and 3 healing fractured ribs (not a clue how I did that). I also had a bone density test which showed the very earliest stages of osteoporosis (sp) so my onco went ahead and put me on Actonel. Within 2 weeks (you take it once a week) I had no hip pain, no feet/ankle and finger pain and have felt SO much better, almost human..... lol I had lower back pain and by physical exam, my onco said it was a disk, but he saw how stressed I was, so he went ahead and sent me for a MRI and, it was a herniated disk, no mets. We are going to feel pain, that had we had it before BC, we wouldn't have thought anything about it, but now, everything scares us unfortunately. Just wanted to give you my experience with bone/joint pain and what I found out. I celebrated having a herniated disk and only we can celebrate something like that ...... lol Hopefully someone will get that bone scan scheduled and find out what's going on and you might want to ask about Actonel or Fosamax to help strengten the bones, because Arimidex will do a number on them. Praying for good results and relief from the pain. Hugs Nancy

Posts.Content: Hi, I had a CT Scan of the chest, chest x-ray, labs and bone scan before my treatment started so they could get an accurate diagnosis. I've heard of very few who didn't get these prior to treatment. You should never feel like you are insulting the oncos intelligence. Your mom has ever right to know about the care she is getting and to question anything that she's unsure of. Chances are this and that, but without the tests/scans, they really don't know for certain where they stand and assuming isn't good enough for me. This is too imporant to assume anything. Good luck

Posts.Title: HER2NEU positive and Breast Cancer

Posts.Content: Jan, First, congrats on almost being done with chemo. You are just about done with everything my friend. I had radiation burns, but radiation should be a breeze compared to chemo. You'll be hit by 3 angles like I was with all the node involvement you have, as I did. Use aloe vera after each treatment (not before) and if you start itching, I was given a RX for "Zone A" cream that really helped. The only thing bad about radiation is you go everyday. I had a hour each way so that made it tougher. You'll see the same people everyday and before long, everyone in the room feels like they know each other. I actually miss seeing some of the people that were taking radiation the same time I was. Not bad enough to go through it again...... lol I like you had ILC. No one tells us that mammograms miss 45% of all BC in women under 50 and doesn't pick up Lobular until we are dx. You gave your sisters good advice. Let us know when all treatment is over and we'll all do the NED dance with you. Most onco consider you NED either on the day you were dx or the day you had the obvious cancer removed, so you're already there Nancy

Posts.Content: Hi Danielle, I've never heard of someone losing their hair after the 2nd day. It's normally said about 14 days after the 1st treatment. I didn't start losing mine until the end of my 3rd treatment........ so much for thinking I'd be the 1 in a 100,000 that didn't lose theirs or whatever the odds were with the 3 chemo's I took together. Fatigue is a given with chemo. Some work all through treatments, some have accumulative affect and get more tired with each treatment. The day of chemo I felt fine, it was day 2 when it hit me. Everyone reacts differently so it's hard to know. Hope she has an easy time of it. Hugs Nancy

I can't believe they don't have one where I live since it's the 2nd largest city in the state. They do the Drive for a Cure here for Komen. A friend if wanting me to go to Chattanooga and do the Race with her and I might do that. Everyone I know says it's amazing at all the pink survivor shirts that are there and all the white shirts for the supporters. I've been told just seeing the thousands there with pink on gives them more hope and God knows, we can use all of that we can get. NASCAR season is beginning, so now I won't have as much free time on my hands, which means not as much time to think.........thinking is a dangerous thing for me...... Let us know how it goes and take pics Tammy Nancy

Posts.Title: Spread the word

Posts.Content: That's another thing that oncos have different views on. I never got any of those shots. I had my labs done 1 week after my 1st chemo, then 2 weeks and then 3 weeks, which was also the time for another chemo. They saw when my counts bottomed out and when they started rebounding. I was then checked 2 weeks after chemo and 3 weeks, which again, prior to the next treatment. My white count always rebounded on it's own, so I never had to get the shots. Some onco's give it regardless and as part of the routine and others give it only if needed. Sue is so right about the hair. My mastectomy when 1st dx and then the simple mastectomy I opted for due to stage, age and kind of BC never bothered me. I'm boobless and doing good. I guess I connected the breast with cancer and I have never missed them, just like I haven't missed the cancer, but my hair. That was the hardest thing for me by far. I had always had long hair and even though I had it cut twice to try and prepare myself, you can't. For me, when it started coming out, I started coming apart. It wasn't long before I accepted it, but when it 1st happens, that seems to be the toughest part. Your hair is part of your identity I guess and it seems cruel for the cancer to take that away from us while we're fighting the beast. It didn't help me at the time, but it really does come back. Mine is as long as it was before chemo. I need to get it cut, but.............. lol She's doing great!!

Posts.Title: A question for Dr. Leo

Posts.Content: Hi, I don't drink, so I can't relate, but I can relate to the fear even when things are clear and living with NED. I'm glad someone was able to help in finding links for you. My only suggestion and it may be the worse thing to do, so I'd check with a counselor or even if possible, find one who's a cancer survivor, regardless of the kind. Alcohol isn't going to help her liver and she's already had mets there once and, Thank God, she's back with NED. Would it help her (you know more of her frame of mind) to remind her about the liver mets and she needs to keep herself as strong and healthy as possible? Or would that just scare her more? There are meds (I take them) for anxiety which has helped me a lot through some of the toughest times. My prayers are with you and it's obvious you love your wife, but you do NOT deserved to be abused!!!!!!!!! Take care of yourself too!!!!!!!!!! Nancy

Posts.Title: immune cells

Posts.Content: I plead stupid. That's over my head... lol I know they have found that ladies that are Her2Neu+++ benefit from having herceptin as part of their 1st round of treatment and I never understood why they waited to give herceptin after a reoccurence had happened. I'm sure they had their reasons. Maybe that was on the back burner in case someone went to stage IV and needed a kick butt drug. I don't know alot about Her2Neu and herceptin since I'm Her2Neu-, but I have friends who are Her2neu+++. I think (and you know I try not to, gives me a headache.. lol) you can only have Adriamycin once. There is Epirubensin which is in the same family as Adriamycin but more aggressive and has fewer side affects that someone could take if it came back, but I think Adriamycin is only a one time thing. I'm sure Leo or someone can correct me if I'm wrong. I'm glad they found that herceptin shows alot of promise as a 1st round treatment. In the 3 years since my dx, I'm amazed at how much they have learned and all the new treatments, nausea meds etc. that are out there to make things a little easier on the ones that are just starting the journey.

Posts.Title: Question

Posts.Content: Hi, YES, find a doctor that will do a biopsy. The only good lump is one in a jar. I too had a negative mammogram and ultra sound but my gut said there was something wrong. I insisted on a biopsy and I was dx with Stage III Invasive Lobular BC. The actual lump, isn't necessarily the total size, IF it is breast cancer. My actual lump was 3.5 cm, but what I had a mastectomy done, they found 2 more cm of cancer in the surrounding tissue. I also had 9 positive lumph nodes out of 16. I have no family history of breast cancer or cancer in general. The only way to be sure if it is cancerous of B9 is with a biopsy. My suggestion is an incisional biopsy beacuse even a needle biopsy can show a false negative. Again, it may not be breast cancer, BUT you won't know until a biopsy is done and if you're like I was, when my gut wasn't comfortable with what I was being told, you won't relax until you have it done. Please keep us posted Praying for B9 Nancy
Posts.Title: Do I get a second opinion?

Posts.Content: I'm just curious. Why does everyone sound like people like myself with many positive nodes, don't have much of a chance? I know it's better not to have them, but there are many ladies that are many years out with alot of node involvement. I guess it's hard to hear over and over again about "poor prognosis". I just became officially 3 years NED with Stage III and I think I'm doing good as does my onco.

Posts.Title: question for the Drs

Posts.Content: Hi Marion, I've written you 3 times and then deleted them. TM's and oncos go from one extreme to the other. A friend of mine before she had her biopsy, had the CA 27-29 done and it was normal, but she had a 9cm tumor and 11+ nodes. Needless to say, they didn't do anymore tumor markers on her. I think they are better at detecting reoccurences then initial dx. I didn't have my 1st one until I was NED a year and my onco did them at each of my 3 month check ups for a year, to see what was normal for me. My last one was in Oct. and my next one will now be in Oct. I'm definately not a doc and I'll let one answer you with more definate answers but wanted to give you a little info that I learned based on my onco's views of TM. He said he would not do any on me during treatment as so many things can cause false positives, as well as false neg. and with the chemo, which is obviously a foreign body going in, he just wouldn't do them. The reason he waited a year was he wanted to be as sure as humanly possible that I was NED, then he could see what the norm was for me. The labs they do, tell a big picture, more then I even realized until recently. Of course the liver enzimes obviously keep an eye on the liver. Calcium levels, tell a lot about the bones, as far as mets go. Some oncos never do any TM. Mine doesn't do the CEA because everything can cause those to go up and down. I know easier said then done, because I freaked when mine went up 5 points and it was still in the low normal and the next time went back down. I was running a fever and that's more then likely what caused the slight change, but to me it was a huge change since they had always been almost identical each time. Try not to think about the TMs, especially at this point. You're getting the chemo regimine that your onco feels is best for your type of cancer and radiation and getting good care. I think a good onco is half the battle and it sounds like you've got one that is very good and truly cares about you as a person, not a number. You're already considered NED because the obvious cancer is gone and this is to get any stray little suckers that might be floating around, so you're on your way and before long, you'll be celebrating your 1 year NED. I don't know what is standard after treatment care, but mine did another CT Scan of my chest after treatment and a year later, did a bone scan (that was because I was hurting in places I hadn't hurt before) and that was fine. The way mine told me was if my tumor markers went up and continued to go up, he'd start checking to see IF it meant the cancer was back somewhere and on the other hand, if I was having problems, like I did when my lower back hurt so bad, that I just knew I had bone mets (he said it was a disk) and even though the TMs were normal, he did an MRI of my lower back and it was a herniated disk thank God. I hope this makes sense because I can confuse myself sometimes.....lol Hang in their girl, you're doing great and before long, you'll be done with treatment and starting your new life after cancer. Hugs Nancy

Posts.Title: Tumor Markers

Posts.Content: Hi CC, If you are post menopausal, you can ask your onco about Arimidex. Everything we take, including tylenol have side affects listed. I had a 3% cance of getting leukemia from one of the chemo's I took, but that 3% chance vs. basically 100% chance the cancer was come back, wasn't a hard decision to make. I'd talk to your onco about your fears and go from there. A lot of the natural remedies also have side affects and what they are made from (the ones I've read about that ladies have talked about) like venom from a poisonous snake, mistletoe extract, which is nothing put poison etc. Good luck

Posts.Title: Tumor Markers

Posts.Content: Hi Mary, I was 43 when dx, so we're around the same age. I started on Tamoxifen because the onco thought I would start having periods again. After a year had passed since my last one and the studies were showing Arimidex to be superior to Tamoxifen, I switched. Arimidex can cause some pretty bad bone and joint pain. Mostly your feet/ankles and hands/fingers. My onco put me on Actonel which is given for osteoporosis since Arimidex also can weaken the bones. Since the 2nd week (take once a week) of me taking Actonel, 95% of the bone and joint pain was gone. I had to have surgery on one of my thumbs because of a "trigger finger" that locked up and I couldn't straighten out. I had 3 other ones. The 3 other ones completely took care of themselves once I started taking Actonel. I'd also get your cholesterol checked after you've been on Arimidex for awhile. It can cause the cholesterol, especially the tryglicerides to be high. Normal is under 150 and mine bounce back and forth between 450-650. Neither zocor or lipitor brought it down, plus the side affects for me of those I hated. I started taking Omega 3, fish oil, and I'll go in next week and get rechecked. Hopefully the Omega 3 will help to bring it down. I know what you mean about feeling like an old lady, but the Actonel hopefully will help you like it has me. Anything is better then cancer. Fosamax didn't help with the bone/joint pain and my stomach couldn't handle it, then I was switched to Actonel and what a blessing!!!!!! Hope this info helps. Oh, also, I noticed even with Actonel, the more I go barefoot, that's when I start having some of the pain in my feet/ankles. If I wear tennis shoes most of the time, I guess it's the support, but I don't have any problems. Nancy

Posts.Content: Hi Lindsey, I'm sorry that you're having to deal with BC on top of everything else you've been through. I don't know anything about the genetic test you're talking about, but I know that I was told that I had a 3% chance of getting leukemia from one of the chemos that I had. I was a Stage III w/9+ nodes, so obviously a 3% chance of getting leukemia and virtually 100% chance of it coming back without chemo was a no brainer. I know this is entirely different then what you're talking about, and I really don't know why I even typed it.....LOL Some days I think I'm a few french fries short of a happy meal....LOL Leo, I'm sure can shed some light on your situation. He checks the board and posts as often as his schedule will allow, but with him being an onco, I have no doubt he can help answer some of your questions. I definately would get a 2nd opinion. I'm not saying the onco you saw is not a good one, but with your age and past history, the more knowledge the better. Please keep us posted and prayers going out to you. Nancy

Posts.Title: DCIS Treatment

Posts.Content: Hi, I'm sorry to hear about your mom's dx. I had a bone scan and CT Scan of my chest to check for cancer in other places, but if it's a full body MRI, that I would think would be as good. This is my personal opinion, so I'm not saying that her surgeon is wrong. I opted for a mastectomy at 43 because my mammogram missed a 5.5 cm tumor and I wanted to be sure there wasn't cancer in any other part of the breast and the only way to know was to have the mastectomy. I also had the other breast removed because of my age (higher risk for recurrence) and Stage etc. I also had Invasive Lobular which is prone to mirror itself in the other breast. Do you know what kind of BC she has? How many nodes were involved? I think the week post surgery is when she could use the help the most. I think that would be perfect timing for you to go visit. The length of chemo and radiation sounds completely normal. Chemo put me into menopause, so it gave me more options of drugs to take since I was estrogen and progesterone positive (cancer fed off hormones). I would think at your mom's age, she has a good chance of the same thing happening to her. Do you know if she's hormone positive? Did they already do a lumpectomy and node removal but didn't get "clean margins"? The hardest part if not being able to lift after having nodes removed, but they are saying she already has nodes involved, so I'm confused on that part.

Posts.Title: Mom Diagnosed - Looking for help

Posts.Content: Hi, 1st I'd read the pathology report and see how she can have a dx of DCIS AND have a lymph node positive. DCIS means incapsulated and hasn't spread outside that area. You can get a 2nd opinion as far as what they think the best treatment plan is. I would put less importance with reconstruction and forcus on dealing with the cancer. How old is she? I had Epirubensin and it was for ILC. I've heard of ladies that had heart problems with AC, even though the ones I've heard of doing that, had pre-existing problems and then they would give Epirubensin. Epirubensin is really good chemo. I had it with STage III and 9+ nodes.

Posts.Title: Looking for those one who are on the same chemo as me - CEF

Posts.Content: Hi Kristen, We were the exact same age when dx and it sucks. I honestly don't know the answer. Have you talked to your onco about having your ovaries removed or get that shot that puts you into MENTALpause? I don't know if the combo of 3 chemos I took made a difference as far as it putting me into menopause or not. My onco fully expected me to start having periods again within 6 months of finishing chemo, but I didn't. I "think" (you know that's dangerous for me... lol) I asked about having my ovaries removed while I was on Tamoxefin and before I knew I was post menopausal, but I can't remember for sure. I just wanted everything removed that produced hormones to give me my best shot since I was Stage III. I'd talk to your onco and ask him the benefits of having your ovaries removed as far as helping to prevent a reoccurence. I'm sure like everything else with this disease, there will be differences of opinion depending on which onco you talk to which is why we stay confused. I really don't want to have surgery #9 (2 weren't BC/reconstruction related) but if it would help me live to be a ripe old age, then I'd do it in a second. I know Arimidex is suppose to kill hormones vs. putting some kind of protector around them so cancer cells can't get to them (that still confuses me), but even with Arimidex, I'd have my ovaries removed if he thought it would be beneficial. So, bottom line Kristen is I've been absolutely no help to you and I'm sorry. I would think having it done would help any er/pr+ and especially when we're "young" and that isn't in our favor, but mine told me it wouldn't help my chances, so I'm lost and confused as well. I'd talk to your onco at your next appt. and see what he/she says. Let me know what you find out and I'm going to ask mine again when I see him and see if he still feels the same way. I know getting through the 1st 2 years is a good thing because it shows our cancer wasn't chemo resistant and wasn't real aggressive, so they may be more apt to say no now because if it's not broke, don't fix it......... I'm as lost as you. I have my rad onco check up tomorrow so I'm having a case of canceritis and if I've made less sense then normal, I'm sorry, just real nervous when it comes to check ups. Hugs Nancy

Posts.Title: ovary supression w/ tamoxifen

Posts.Content: Mia, Look at my bio compared to yours........ I have NO plans of going anywhere anytime soon If I went by stats that are probably 5 years old, I would have a 50/50 chance or a little better of not having a reoccurence within 5 years. You being Stage II with a tiny tumor, the ACS stats for that are 85% chance you won't have a recurrence in 5 years. Those are old stats, and they are better now and we are all individuals. My best friend died 12/1/04 who was dx Stage III, one day before me. I'm over 3 1/2 years NED. I know some feel that if you have node involvement then that's the worse news possible......... we were treated very aggressively, we're er/pr+ and Her2 negative.....those are in our favor. Of course er/pr neg. and Her2 positive can also do great. It's a crap shoot, but based on what dx, you've got VERY good chances of never dealing with this beast again!!!! I promise, it gets easier. You've just completed treatment and you're beyond scared, just as I was. We feel like we're not doing anything anymore to kill the cancer since we're done with treatment. Our security blanket has been snatched away from us and it's terrifying. The 1st year I would get nervous 2 months before my check up and they were every 3 months. Now, I get nervous a couple of days before. In Oct. I have a bone scan, chest x-ray, tumor markers, regular labs and check up. I do get extremely nervous when it's test time (I have the bone scan and chest x-ray once a year) and there's no amount of xanax that will completely calm my nerves down, but that's once a year. I can honestly say that I think about cancer everyday, but it's more of a passing thought. It doesn't consume me like it use to. I use to live and breathe cancer. Go to sleep thinking about it and wake up thinking about it, but I PROMISE the more time that passes and you're NED, the easier it gets. I think we'll always have times of fears especially when something hurts that didn't use to (or we think it didn't use to) and will always have that black cloud hanging over our heads, BUT for me, once my hair started coming back and I started looking not so tired all the time and had some "normalcy" in my life again, it started getting easier. My onco doesn't believe in stats. If I ask him, he'll tell me what the ACS stats are, but he doesn't like numbers because we aren't numbers. My PET showed 2 hot spots in Dec 2002 and I was dx as you can see by my bio at bottom 2/14/02 and my last treatment/rads was 9/11 (I know, what dates). The hot spots were down my node disection side and my thyroid. The node disection side was healing still from the surgery and my thyroid ended up getting damaged during radiation and now I'm on synthroid. PETs are great (especially dogs and cats.....sorry, trying to make you smile but they are very prone to show false positives. Last year when I had my chest x-ray done, it showed I had 3, healing fractured ribs.......I'm on Arimidex, but they don't know if that did it, radiation could have caused it, or when I had a sinus infection and coughing caused it. An infection will also cause a PET to show a hot spot sometimes because it picks up any abnormal activity and inflamation is "abnormal" activity as well. I know easier said then done but we've all been where you are my friend but try to relax, get the sinuses cleared up and they can do another chest x-ray. Does your onco do tumor makers? Mine did them a year after I had been NED for a year, just to see what was normal for me and now does them once a year. He's not a big fan of them, but if they are elevated and keep going up, then he'll start running scans etc. It's a little less then 2 months before my tests/scans and I'm nervous, but not consummed. Now, about 2-3 weeks before, I'll be wondering the same thing you are right now but it's because of the scans. I'm not afraid of the tests, but of the results. That's once a year case of pure, raw nerves and that's alot better then in the beginning when I stayed that way. Hang in there and you'll see, it DOES get easier, thank God. If you need to talk, send me a personal message and I'll be sure and check throughout the day. Hugs and prayers for easier times that will come. Nancy

Does she have primary bone cancer or Breast Cancer that has come back in her bones? There is a big difference. Sounds like your mom is a fighter and that goes a long ways.

Posts.Title: Trying to cope

Posts.Content: Hi Susan, It really surprised me when I saw it was made from venom of a poisionous snake....never expected to see that. Yes, Talladega is where Nascar goes twice a year for racing. I'm a huge Kevin Harvick fan and I promised myself that I was going to start doing things I enjoyed after I finished up with treatment. It was last weekend and I had a great time. Never thought about cancer which is great. My driver missed the 25 car wreck they had, but was in the middle of the last wreck with only 2 laps to go. His car didn't quite look the same as it did and since the same driver caused both wrecks, I know mine wasn't happy, but he's learned not to say what's on his mind or it will cost him with money and points. As far as your other question, no, I don't think we ever quit worrying. I will say that prior to my check ups, I don't start worrying until a few days to a week before, where in the beginning, I'd worry 2 months before and I saw him every 3 months. It does get easier, but unless they come up with a Cure or something we can take that is 99% (since nothing is 100%) affective in preventing reoccurences, we'll have that black cloud hanging over our heads. My onco did tell me that the 1st 2 years is a big milestone since most reoccurences happen within the 1st 2 years. He said by getting past that 2 year point shows that I wasn't chemo resistant and that my cancer wasn't real aggressive. It's been a little over 3 years now and we all know it can come back after 3, 5, 10, 15 or anytime it wants, I feel a little more relaxed about it and where I wouldn't plan anything in advance out of fear that it would come back, I have plans to be back in Talladega in Oct. for the 2nd race there of the season, so there does come a time that you start living again. I hope that helps. It may have happened sooner if not for going through a divorce the last 3 years at the same time of my dx and treatment and my ex still is playing his games and keeping me in court every 4 months..........Dirty cop, corrupt city equals nothing but trouble for me. He's a good con man that's for sure. Anyway as usual I'm rambling. Take care and know all of this will get easier

Posts.Title: Lachesis Mutus for hot flashes

Posts.Content: Hi tmma, When you get to the UK, I'd be asking her onco when they plan on finding out if it's a reccurence of BC or a new primary. Also, is she not on any bone strengthner? Usually when they do rads to bone mets, they also give me Aredia, Xomeda (ap) or another bone strengthner that makes the bones stronger so the pain is a lot less. The UK is where we get our info from a lot because the studies are able to be done more timely then in the U.S., but someone is missing something it seems like with your mom. I know many that have mets to the bones that have been stable for many many years and are virtually pain free. I'm not a doctor, but it might be time for a 2nd opinion. It may be that you learn a lot more about your mom's condition when you get there since no one is asking questions. Please keep us posted and you take care of YOU too!!! You're all in my prayers.

Posts.Title: Clinics in Mexico as adjuvant treatment

Posts.Content: Hi Worriedmom, It could be that they didn't get clear pictures and need more. If they see something on the mammogram and want to do an ultra sound, then I would insist that a biopsy be done on the area they see microcalifications or a lump. With you having a hx of BC in your family, you need to be very pro-active in getting mammograms and anything found removed. I could feel my lump and had no hx of Breast Cancer in my family, but my mammogram missed it and so did the ultra sound. The is NO test that can say if something is B9 or not, only a biopsy can do that. The tests are to show any abnormal findings. If it is a mass they see, it could be too small for you to feel if you're doing Self Breast Exams (which is how I found mine), which would be good news. I felt great when I was dx and most ladies I've talked to did too. My lymph nodes weren't swollen, but I had 9 + for cancer, so for the most part, there are no symptoms. Have the other films done. Again, I would insist on having a lump or cluster of microcalifications removed and not a needle biopsy, those aren't always accurate. The only good lump is one in a jar. I had just turned 43, again with no hx in my family. From this day forward, do monthly self breast exams and get your annual mammograms. Please let us know what you find out and please do NOT let the fear of having breast cancer, stop you from doing what you need to do. If it is, ignoring it won't make it go away, just more time to grown.

Posts.Title: just got mammogram report

Posts.Content: Hi, Things are done very different in the U.S. I had a mastectomy, the entire breast removed because I had a large tumor. They also remove my lymph nodes and 9 out of 16 of them were positive for breast cancer as well. I had chemo and radiation and am doing well. There are side affects to chemo, but I've heard of very few that had alot of trouble. You stay tired, but really, that's the main side affect. There in an oncologist, Leo, that checks this forum when he's not on duty and has some time, and he will be alot of help to you. I'm not sure what to say since treatment there and here are completely different. Chemo may have side affects, BUT it's temporary and it's meant to KILL cancer cells that are left behind. Without chemo, the cancer continues to grow. I wouldn't say that if the dx had been a Stage I, even though most are taking chemo with the lower stages too, but if you were in the US, there would be surgery to remove the cancerous breast, all lymph nodes removed and chemo and radiation done. Has it spread to the liver, lungs, bones or anywhere? What kind of test have they done? Hugs and prayers

Posts.Title: Breast cancer

Posts.Content: Unfortunately, it's not unusual these days to see women in their 30's or even late 20's being dx. Family hx only accounts for between 10-15% of all breast cancer dx. Mammograms, even though they are the best we have and I highly recommend women get them because they DO find BC at early stages, they miss 45% of all BC in women under 50 (under that is considered young and higher risk) and 35% over 50. I wish they'd tell us these things before we're dx. It seems many doctors still think family hx is a huge factor and that mammograms results are full proof. I was told I was fine and to come back in a year........ Good thing I didn't listen.

Posts.Title: The day is almost here..........ahhhhhhhhh

Posts.Content: Hi Shelly, I honestly had no problem with have both breast removed (just wish I had done it at the same time) but when my hair started coming out......psycho woman emerged.... Mine didn't start coming out until right before my 4th round of FEC. The nurses looked up the chemos to see if there was a small % that didn't lose all their hair and there was but only on 1 of them, but I convenienced myself, I wasn't going to lose it. My dad happened to be at my house when I went to the bathroom to brush it and I felt so sorry for him. I didn't just cry, I was squalling and cussing the disease and pretty much had a meltdown. I'd say within a few days or a week, I accepted it as it was, gone. I wasn't smart like you and had it cut off. I had 3 haircuts before chemo, so my hair went from 1/2 way down my back to right under my ears, but let it come out at it's own speed (fast). I found a sweather hanging in the closet when I was moving and it was clean, but had alot of strands of my hair on the inside of it. BUT now it's back to half way down my back and hard to believe I ever lost it.....my hair not my mind, that's a given... lol You'll be amazed at how quick time goes and chemo is over. You're doing great!!!!!!!!!!! Hugs Nancy

Posts.Title: The day is almost here..........ahhhhhhhhh

Posts.Content: Lance Armstrong was in great shape when he was dx and had been eating healthy. Personally, I have no doubt that the chemo killed his cancer. Will it come back, who knows. No one knows if or when they will have a reoccurence regardless of stage. All I know is he's alive and doing great. I have no doubt had I not had chemo, I would have been gone a couple of years ago. I did what my onco recommended, I did alot of research and I'm here 3 1/2 years later. Everyone needs to do what is best for them. Everyone is entitled to their opinion. I personally also don't think it's healthy to dwell on the disease and to enjoy life, so having said that. Someone else will have to debate with you on this topic. I do know the longer someone goes without a reoccurence, the better chance they have of beating it again if it does come back. Those who have reoccuences within the 1st couple of years, usually don't do well because treatment wasn't as effective. I could get run over by a car tonight and die. There are no guarentees in life, but I'm going to do what gives me the best chance. Have a good day. I'm off to do something besides think and talk about cancer, and no, that's not called burying my head in the sand, it's called " Life after cancer"

Posts.Title: Mother-in-law refuses to see dr. and we're ALL concerned

Posts.Content: Hi, Me personally won't use anything that isn't FDA approved or my onco hasn't recommended, but that's just me. This is what I found on it and based on what it's made from, and what it does, which is works as a blood thinner, scares me. There isn't much info on it except for site that tell you to buy it from them. Check out what it's made from. I've heard alot of women on Effexor for menopause systems. Chemo put me into menopause and I was on Tamoxifen and Effexor, and for me, it didn't help. Once I changed to Arimidex, I had no more hot flashes or night sweats. I went from Effexor to Paxil for depression mid treatment, so I'm assuming Tamoxifen was the culprit as far as menopause side affects. I'm sure you'll hear from other ladies that take Effexor as that's the most used med I've seen to combat hot flashes etc. Lachesis Mutus This homeopathic remedy comes from the poisonous venom of the bushmaster snake. Lachesis mutus has potent effects on the blood and central nervous system. The most important effect of Lachesis mutus is its blood-thinning, or anti-coagulant, function. This action enhances blood flow and facilitates the healing process by hastening the removal of toxins from the blood. The remedy is effective against many bleeding disorders. Lachesis mutus is prescribed for relieving depression, palpitations, migraines and other throbbing headaches, tonsillitis, anal fissures, hemorrhoids, rectal bleeding, nosebleeds, bleeding gums, prolonged menstrual periods, poor circulation, cold extremities, a swollen or inflamed tongue, and all types of skin ulcers and wounds. It is also used to ease menopausal symptoms.

Posts.Title: Lachesis Mutus for hot flashes

Posts.Content: Hi, To some extent, I can understand the fear of the unknown, but when I found my lump, I went and got it checked. Even though I had no hx, which found out later that has little to do with most BC's and I was "young" I knew the lump didn't belong there. I called a surgeon myself when I was told to come back in a year because the mammogram didn't pick up what I and my doc clearly felt. Fear is very real when it comes to cancer, but ignoring it just makes it grow and spread. I pray it's not in her lungs, but it is suspicious. Ladies are Stage IV and chemo can kick butt and keep them stable and I know of one lady that had IBC, had it spread to her lungs, nodes and liver and she went back NED (No Evidence of Disease) and has been there for 2 years. Stable is the most realistic hope, but stable is a good thing. I pray she'll take treatment. As Jim said, be there for her, help when you feel you can and if she doesn't want you to, she'll say something. I wanted to be as independant as I could, especially living alone and not wanting my parents to make the drive to help, but when I needed help, I would ask. Everyone handles it different and you'll know. Having her family around and being supportive and just knowing she has people that love her will be a big help Keep us posted!!

Posts.Title: Oncologic In Vitro Chemoresponse Assays

Posts.Content: Hi Amy, I didn't have nipple discharge, but noticed a lump even though my mammogram was "normal". I've heard of ladies that have had discharge and from what I understand, it can go either way. I have no hx of cancer of any kind in my family, and was dx not long after I turned 43. I'm praying your results will be B9, but if they aren't, we're here. If you'll look at my dx, I had so many things against me, but 5 1/2 years later, I'm doing great and NED (No evidence of disease). There's no doubt, it's scary not knowing. Having the lumps removed is absolutely the right thing to do. There is not test besides a biposy that can tell if it is or isn't cancer. I had the excisional biopsy, but I've heard of a lot of ladies having the kind you're having. Keep us posted on the results.

Posts.Title: New here - need to have a biopsy

Posts.Content: Just buy her a new computer of her own If she's like most of us, there's a lot of cat napping when you go through chemo and she'll probably find herself up late and up early and napping on and off. I still have problems with sleep. I think my body got use to not sleeping through the night, it doesn't know how to anymore. BUT, the dogs and cat remember all to well what time breakfast comes, so no matter what time I fall asleep, I'm up by 6 to a cat on my chest and one dog staring me in the face........LOL Keep us posted on what kind of chemo she'll be getting and hopefully we can give her some pointers. No doubt she's a compassionate lady working with cancer patients, but I'm sure she feels like a fish out of water when she's the patient. Most onco's consider the day of surgery, when the visable cancer is removed as the beginning of her living with NED (No Evidence of Disease) and some even the dx date so even though it doesn't feel like it, she's kickin butt already Is she getting AC and then Taxol or Taxotere or 4 rounds of AC only? I noticed that she had node involvement, how many nodes were cancerous? I had 9 and my onco said they would have treated me the same way, very aggressively even if I had fewer nodes or for that matter in my case, no nodes since my tumor was so large. If you or Karen are up late at night and need to talk, just send me an e-mail and there's a good chance I'll be on line or it won't be long. Hugs and prayers to you both.

Posts.Title: First time post!

Posts.Content: Hi, I'm so sorry to hear about your mom having a reoccurence. It's amazing and makes no sense how after 15 years those cells are still lingering. You'd think one time around with this crap is more then enough. From what I've read latey and Leo can correct me if I'm wrong......and he will. lol Some say take Tamoxifen for 2 - 3 years then switch to Arimidex, Femara or one of those. Others say use Arimidex as 1st line of treatment. I was dx Stage III (mammogram missed a 5.5 cm tumor....bio below) and I was put on Tamoxifen after treatment because my onco thought I'd start having my periods again because of my age. After I didn't have one for 6 months after I was done, he did a blood test and chemo put me into MENTALpause. At that time more and more was known about Arimidex and my onco and I both agreed that Arimidex was the way to go. I've been taking it now for over 2 years. My personal opinion, is with your mom being Stage IV, I would go with Arimidex. She needs to sit down with her onco and discuss it and they decide which is the best way to go. Arimidex has been proven to be superior to Tamoxifen in preventing reoccurences and given to Stage IV ladies. I don't know how it works with Stage IV, but I didn't start anything until after I finished chemo. They might put her on Arimidex or one of the others while she's taking chemo for the liver mets. I've seen many do that. If she took Tamoxifen during her 1st dx, I don't know if she can take it again or not. I never thought of that. I hope I've been of some help, but I'm sure Leo (he's the onco that started this forum) can tell you more and in a much shorter post Hugs and prayers to you and your mom and let's kick some cancer butt Nancy

Posts.Title: My mom has metastatic breast cancer...

Posts.Content: The only thing your mom could have taken the 1st time being pre-menapausal would have been Tamoxifen. Arimidex and the other are for post menopausal women only and as far as I know, none of them were around 15 years ago. As far as I know, the only difference in the Aromatase inhibitor are the side affects. Again, Leo will know more as well as some of the other ladies, but normally after someone is on Tamoxifen for 5 years, they go on Femara. Starting out on something else, or as a 1st line of med is Arimidex. I think it's an individual opinion of the onco as to which he likes better. I have seen someone start with Tamoxifen and after 5 years, they go on Arimidex. I don't think and haven't read any studies that says one of the inhibitors is better then the other, but Arimidex has been out longer and have more studies on that.

Posts.Title: newbie-lumpectomy 4/01/05

Posts.Content: I wasn't scared waiting for the results, because my mammogram was normal and they said my ultra sound showed I just had a cyst, but my gut said to get the lump out. The surgeon and my PCP both said I had nothing to worry about. No family hx, I was young etc. etc. I was dx Stage III Invasive Lobular BC. When I got that news, it was an emotional roller coaster from hell. I was scared, in disbelief, I didn't want to die and then I got mad, really mad at the cancer and I got in the fighting mode of kicking cancer's butt. I've heard of one 19 year old that had BC in the whole time since I was dx and she had been dx a few years before me, so I've only head of one is about 9 years. Anything is possible, but it's highly unlikely that you have breast cancer. Please let us know when you get the results. If you are wanting to quit smoking, do it now before you're so addicted it's even harder. Take it from someone who knows. The longer you smoke, the harder it is to quit because it becomes such a huge part of your every day life.

Posts.Title: I'm 18, waiting for results...

Posts.Content: Don't say most recent dx of BC, I've had only one and I pray it's the only one........ With as much that's in my bio, I'm sure it looked like it had to be more then one, but I ramble in even them..... lol 'No, I'm done with reconstruction unless they come up with a less invasive way to do it. I've had 8 surgeries, 6 were connected to the BC/mastectomies and the attempted reconstruction, one from, more then likely the Arimidex and the other is questionable. I tore the ligament (sp) completely in my wrist, but didn't have any kind of injury or accident that would have caused that much damage. So not sure if chemo, Arimidex weakens the muscles and ligaments too or if I'm just that lucky...... lol If I could do it over, I would have seen a PS before my mastectomy, but at the time I was dx on a Thur. Valentine's Day, went to an out of town surgeon that I wanted to do the MRM on Monday and had the MRM on Thur., so not much time to think, which was good for me. Who knows what else they will have in a couple of years. I told myself if I made it the 5 years, which I plan on then I might consider trying again, but definately not until then. I've retired as a professional surgery patient..... lol My last one I had prior to BC is when I was 3 and it was my tonsils. I don't do anything in moderation.......UGH Your PS really did do a good job. I think I got up to 200CC and had to have saline removed after that, so I can see by just what I had that ours looked alike, you just had more and it worked. Congrats!!!!!!!!!!!! The boobless one.... lol Nancy

Posts.Title: E-string

Posts.Content: Hi Liz, I know you wrote to Leo and I wouldn't begin to give advice on something I don't know anything about. You said your onco discharged you this year? In the states, you see your onco every 3 months for the first couple of years and then every 6 months and after 5 years it goes to once a year. I'm sure there is some various to this, but that's in general. I can't believe that he just basically said you were on your own after a year. I'd call him and make an appt. or get an earlier appt. with your surgeon, or even get one with your PCP and any of them can order a MRI or CT Scan of your head. I don't know and haven't heard of some of the things you mentioned in your post, so again, I'm not suggesting that it does or doesn't sound like mets, but you can't just sit there and worry about it. Call those docs and get in with the 1st one you can. The waiting and wondering and worrying is a horrible thing. Best wishes and please keep us posted You're in my prayers Nancy

Posts.Title: Possible brain mets?

Posts.Content: Hi Julie, Arimidex can cause bad bone and joint pain. Mine was so bad it was hard for me to get out of bed, my feet/ankles hurt so bad. I also got trigger fingers. I told my onco about it and even though I don't have osteoporosis, he put me on Actonel (it prevents it too) and the 2nd time I took it, the pain in my feet/ankles, hands and fingers was gone. The trigger fingers even quick locking up and my fingers are completely normal. You might want to ask your onco about that. Let me know what he/she says and how it works for you. It was such a blessing to me. NO MORE PAIN and Arimidex is such a good drug, I didn't want to get off of it, especially with my age/stage. Also, get your cholesterol checked. Arimidex can cause that to go sky high. My triglicerites have been as high a 725. I'm on crestor now and get it rechecked later this month. It doesn't affect everyone, but a friend of mine who's on Femara is having the same problems. I'll happily take another pill to keep this cancer away

Posts.Title: Mother-in-law refuses to see dr. and we're ALL concerned

Posts.Content: Hi, I'm so sorry to hear about your mom's cancer coming back. This disease is beyond cruel and can rear it's ugly head anytime. We need a cure NOW. You said your mom took the chemo "pill". Did she have chemo or only take something like Tamoxifen? Are they giving her any bone strengthener or just did radiation? Radiation is very common for bone mets, but most I know also take something to strengthen the bones as well. Please know that your family is in my prayers. I've been dx with Breast Cancer had my best friend was dx as well, so I've been on both sides of the patient and the care giver. Being the caregiver is an emotional roller coaster itself. I'm sure someone who's dealing with mets will be able to give you more info.

Posts.Content: I know nothing about those kinds of biopsies, I had the lump surgerically removed. Ask you surgeon about Versaid. It's the I don't give a S*** shot and you really don't....You have no idea what's going on but when you wake up unlike for general anesthesia, you are wide awake.

Posts.Title: Excruciating pain during stereotactic biopsy

Posts.Content: Hi Shelly, OUCH sounds like an understatement. Bless your heart that has to be miserable. I used 100% aloe vera after each radiation treatment and then when I started burning, my rads onco told me to use the liquid Vitamin E to put on after treatment. About a week, maybe 10 days before I was done, I had blisters on my neck from where the rads hit me and it was right there where you sweat and that burned SO bad. My rads onco. gave me "Zone A" cream that helped with the itching. It wasn't horrible at the end, but it wasn't fun by any means. About a week after radiation, my chest looked black (remember I had to get hit and hit hard because of being stage III and hit from 3 angles, not 2) and I don't know how many layers peeled, but it was fried, but no pain because it was dead skin and the skin under it was tan, but no pain. Well, maybe your oozing wasn't as gross as you thought after reading what I just wrote.... lol Just think, your final part of your journey is almost over....... congrats!!!!!
